APCSP Study Guide

Read this 5 months, 5 weeks, 5 days, and 5 minutes before the exam

Take a look at the official reference sheet. Make sure you are comfortable with the programming terminology presented. If anything on that sheet confuses you, don’t panic! I will cover every single symbol on that sheet in this guide.

Numbers

Binary representations can take on two possible values. A bit, or binary digit, is the fundamental unit of information for a computer, represented by a or . A byte is a group of 8 bits.

Kilobyte (KB) ≈ 1000 bytes
Megabyte (MB) ≈ 1000 kilobytes
Gigabyte (GB) ≈ 1000 megabytes
Terabyte (TB) ≈ 1000 gigabytes
Petabyte (PB) ≈ 1000 terabytes
Exabyte (EB) ≈ 1000 petabytes

Binary is a system of counting. A counting system is defined by how many unique digits are available in that system, or the base of the system. To indicate the base of a number, write the base as a subscript e.g. .

System Base Digits Example
Binary
Decimal
Hexadecimal

You learned in elementary school that a number has a ones place, a tens place, a hundreds place, and so on. We could say that consists of hundreds, tens, and ones. Mathematically, we write this as . Notice that the orange numbers are powers of ; we can write numbers of any base in this form, where the is replaced with the base of the number.

In general, where are digits and is the base of the number,

represents the amount of unique values a number with base and a maximum of digits can represent. For example, a binary number with 5 digits can represent values (from to .)

“How many times more values can a 16 digit binary number hold over a 4 digit binary number?”

The answer is .

ASCII (American Standard Code for Information Interchange) is a raw text format. It maps numerical values to characters. Familiarize yourself with the table (don’t memorize it!). Know that uppercase letters have smaller values than lowercase letters.

Hexadecimal values have base . Each digit can represent values, -. Since , each digit of a hexadecimal value represents 4 bits. Subsequently, 2 digits represent a byte (4 bits for each digit). Hexadecimal is used because it can represent more information per digit than binary or decimal.

A common use of hexadecimal is to represent color values through color codes 6-digit hexadecimal values. These values are based on the RGB color model. The screen you are looking at right now adds red, green, and blue light together to represent color.

Byte 1 represents the red value. Byte 2 represents the green value. Byte 3 represents the blue value.

# __ __ __ __ __ __               This is the standard form of a color code, or hex code.

“Which color code has the highest green intensity?” #B7E287 #EFBD27 #013CFF

The second byte represents green, so compare those: E2BD3C

def what?
  42
end
